div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,590] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880
Editor and Manager - - R. Swelling
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1906

div.head: EUROPEANS AND EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM.
div.p: The "Lewa's" campaign against the Franco- Egyptian Press is being vigorously pursued; and one would imagine from the pertinacity with which Mustapha Kamel rates his critics that lie-believed that his influence .among the European colony has not waned since the end of 1903. We should like to point out that whatever such influence he possessed is lost beyond recall. Italians, Frenchmen, and Greek* who read the Pasha's articles in support of the Turkish claims realised that the success of the Pan-Islamic policy woultl have madtrEgvpt uninhabitable by Europeans; we will say more, —by civilised men, within ten years...French-

men who understood the full significant of their country's task in Northern Africa realised that France was completing the of Imperial Rome, knew that Pan Islamic, was a menace; that, whatever their sympathies for Egyptian Nationalism in its old spirit between the spirit of Pan-Islamism and the spirit of France there must be war. Those who hailed with joy the separation between Chur h and State, who felt that the gravest error of Napoleon III. was his support of the temporal [lower of the Pope, were unprepared to salaam to a new combination of spiritual and temporal power, even though a Sultan and Khalif directed its forces. Men remembered that they were Europeans first and that the message of the prophets of Pan-Islamism held no hope for them. They were "intrus"—that was all;

Such has been Mustapha Kamel's one achievement. He has forced the Europeans of union, he has created an opposition formidable from the point of view of wealth courage, and intelligence to his policy. The Priti-h colony realised the position equally rapidly and we believe that the excellent relations that now exist between the European colonies arc in great part caused by the activity of the muchadvertised Mustapha. We have realised that, whatever international disputes, différences of language, customs, and institutions divide us, we are civilisers and progressive men with no love for reactionary intrigues and retrogressive programmes. Our Tribune will no doubt quote his advocacy of an Egyptian Parliament, of Universities of Free Education, of every species of progressive idea in his defence. We have but one answer to give—an answer couched in the form of a question: How long would all these things survive the entry of the Turkish Army9 that would inevitably follow the withdrawal of the British Occupation 1 Not a year 1

div.head: EGYPT AND THE ITALIAN RAILWAYS
div.p: It is sincerely to be hoped that now that such a powerful company as the Hamburg- American Line have embarked on their new service between- Naples and Alexandria, they will be able to exert some pressure to improve Italian railway communications. As long as the Italian railways are run in the existing deplorable manner, neither Naples over Brindisi will over be able to satisfactorily compete with Marseilles as ports of embarkation for Egypt, and now that Trieste has recently been brought into direct communication with Germany, it will be even able to hold its own-with Marseilles. • ' ■

Italy would be the most delightful country to pass through in order to get to Egypt, were its railway system better organised, and we are glad to see that the Italians are at last working lip to the need for improvement/ Thu Rome correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" wrote to that newspaper on Thursday lost that the railway question is assuming a very grave aspect, owing to the frequent disasters, the daily augmenting delays arrival of trains, and the complete lack of sufficient material for the needs of the growing traffic. The southern provinces are threatening u serious agitation, seeing that their wine trade injured by the want, of railway cars. To this must be added the shameful indiscipline among the railway officials, who are rough, insolent, and disobliging towards the public'. The problem is worth being agitated even in the foreign Press, as tourists suffer more than anybody else from ties situation, while they bring into Italy over 300,000,000 francs (£12,000,000) every year.

div.head: THE CECIL MOND PAPYRI
div.p: The long-expected volume, "Aramaic Papyri Discovered at Assouan" has at length been published, 'i he manuscripts are edited by Professors Sayce and Cowley, with notes by M. H. Seymour de Ricci. As is well known, these papyri, which are now in the Cdro. Maseum, were secured by Lidy William Cecif aüd Mr. Robert Mond.

Some four years ago the first really important Aramaic papyrus was edited for the French Academy by Professor Enting. la 1903 Prof es or Cowley published another containing 16 lines of legible writing which come from Elephantine and is now in the Bodleian library. The doomists now given from Assouan are dated in many years of the fifth century B. C., and conclusively prove, as the previoas Aramaic papyri bad foreshadowed, the existence of a Jewish Colony in Upper Egypt.
The importance of the newlengthy Hebrao- Aramaic texts fir the study of the vocabulary of the later books of the Old Testament and the whole of the Hebrew Apochrypha, cannot by over-estimated.

div.head: THE SULTANS GERMAN CHEFS
div.p: We have only quite recently been "officially informed" of the fact that the Sultan's German physician his placed his Majesty upon "special régime." This seems an unkind ont at the cuisine of the Vaterlàad, for Abdul Hamid bas, ever since the visit paid to Constantinople by the Kaiser, dore the graceful thing, aid employed three German cooks to provide his daily viands. Before that a French 6h f reigned supreme. Toe actual daily cost is almost incredible, most of the food, however, giving to retainers," etc. The Sultan himself is said to be a small eater, while each dish destined or his own previous Consumption is veiled by the Grand Vizier, as it leaves the kitchen and bile "piping hot," while, to make assurance double sure, the First Gentleman in baa to taste the plat immediately the seal has boue tel sa fly and bel ire it is conveyed to the lips of his august\ master.

div.head: H.M.S terrible
div.p: H.M.S. Terrible entered the Suez end of the Canal at 6 o'clock yesterday morning en route to Malta.

div.head: A Forecast
div.p: Given a second, we should have to fight a second Tel-el-Kebir in Egypt.—Douglas Story, in the "Tribune.''

div.head: Beyrout Harbour
div.p: The Turkish Government have approved the plans for the extension by ten metres of the quay of Beyrout harbour.

div.head: School of Telegraphy
div.p: A new school of telegraphy is -to be established on Government Railway land near Demar-dash station, on the MataTieh line.

div.head: The Budget.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works is completing the budgetary estimates for 1907, and will shortly submit them to the Ministry.

div.head: "Al Lewa."
div.p: Our contemporary "Al Lewa" promises its readers that its Anglo-French edition, of which so much has been heard, will appear on January 1.

div.head: Sudden Death.
div.p: A Dative lady died suddenly in Cairo railway station on Tuesday, just as she was taking train for Farshont accompanied by her daughter.

div.head: Ivory Sales.
div.p: The total weight of ivory delivered in London for the quarterly sales, which were held on Toe dsy, was just over 66 tons, of which 38 came from Egypt.

div.head: Rudolph Home.
div.p: The Rudolph Home, Alexandria, gratefully acknowledges the receipt of £1 from M. Jacques Aghion and parcels of clothing from Mme. J. Aghion and M. Alex. J. skouffos.

div.head: Ports and lighthouses.
div.p: The tender submitted by Messrs. Sozzarini and Stiénon on the ,20th inat has been succeeded for the supply of 4,000 sq.m, of paving stones to the Ports and Lights Administration. New Barracks.
The foundation stone of the new barracks to be erected for the Egyptian Army near Koub- beh was laid a few days ego. It is expected that the building will be completed in eight months' time.

div.head: Irregularities at Tor.
div.p: Accusations of irregularity have been brought against certain Government officials at Tor, and the Ministry of the Interior has deputed Ibrahim Bey Halim to proceed there and institute inquiries.
Thomas Cook and son (Egypt).

div.head: Thomas Cook and son (Egypt).
div.p: The coupons due on November I next on the Five per Cent. First Mortgage Debentures of Thomas Cook and Son (Egypt) (Limited) will be paid by the London and Westminster Bank, Temple Bar Branch out that date

div.head: Agricultural Bank Bonde.
div.p: Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to allow the follow ing security to be quoted in the Official List : — Agricultural Bank of Egypt—£1,570,000 Sterling Three and-a Half per Cent. Guaranteed Bonds. (Renewed application).

div.head: Department of Public Health.
div.p: Drs. William F. C. MacCarthy Morrogb, Ange Barbarigos, and Mahmoud Sherif, Mr. Carl Jung, dentist, and Messrs Nicolas Jean, Pierre A. Angelidis, Isaac Elic, Biohara Madi, and Arghiri Tchilopouloa, chemists, have received authorizations from the Ministry of the Interior to practice in Egypt.

div.head: Distinguishing Badges.
div.p: The students of the Khédivial Law School, desirous of distinguishing themselves from the students of other schools, row wear a badge bearing the motto "Justice is the basis of Government." The badges, which are worn in the buttonholes of their boats, were struck in Paris.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records a fresh case at Suez and a death in hospital at Port Said. To-day's bulletin records a fatal case at Alexandrie, the victim being a native boy who was found dead at the Ragheb Pasha esbeh. The body was found in Sunday last, but it was only today that a bacteriological examination determined the cause of death. A fresh case is always reported from Suez.

div.head: A Unique Institution.
div.p: Amongst all modern institutions in Egypt, one of the most nestle is undeniably the Berlin School, which, owing to the rapidity and efficiency of the Berlitz Method, is of great advantage to our cosmopolitan population. Nowadays the most difficult idiomatic expressions are made possible for everyone to acquire. One is convinced of this when seeing in Cairo (1, Sharia Ksmel) and in Alexandria (12, me Rosette) the progress made ty the pupils in their study of French, English, Arabic, Italian, German, Greek, etc. [Adv.t]

div.head: Alexandria's New Hotel.
div.p: The Savoy Palace Hotel, belonging to the • l'alaoe Hotels of Egypt Company, which has been built in Reset tread, is now nearing completion, and it is expected that this sum. toons hostelry will be opera to the public about the end of November. The management of the hotel has been confided to M. A. Auber, old Geneva, and patrons may fool assured of, every modern comfort being supplied. The hotel, which is conveniently situated in the most fashionable part of Alexandria, will be furnished by the famous furnishing houses of Kriegor, of Paris, and Maple, of London. It will contain 150 rooms, including a number of apartments with bathrooms attached.

div.head: THE FRONTIER COMMISSION. TURKISH VIEW OF DELIMITATION
div.p: Miralai Owen Bey and Naoum Bey Shukeir returned to Cairo from the frontier about 11.80 last night. Both are in excellent health, and express themselves as satisfied with the results of their mission. The total number of boundary pillars, or rather posts, laid down between Rafeh and Mufrsk, amount to eighty-nine, and these will be replaced later by stone beacons.

We are informed that the Turkish Commissioners have arrived at Damascus, where they are said to have informed a representative of the "Moayad'' that the frontier as delimitated is purely administrative, and can in no- tense be regarded as a political frontier between Syria and Egypt.

div.head: THE TERRIBLE YEMEN
'TURKISH BATTALION REDUCED TO FORTY MEN.
div.p: According to the statements made by some of 'he troops returning from the Yemen expedition, the battalions on their way home have been reduced to an alarming extent, largely owing to sickness and privation.
Thus it is alleged that twelve battalions, which were embarked on one transport, on being landed at Alexandretta, in Syria, were reduced to from two hundred to forty men each.
Some of the men landed at Alexandretta were too weak to continue the journey on foot into the interior, and have been brought to Smyrna, whence they hope to reach their homes.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM IN ALGERIA.
div.p: The Prefect of Constantinople, interviewed by a representative of the "E ho de Paris'' with regard to the unrest in Algeria, said there was certainly no smoke without fire. He admitted that it was only too true that disorders were taking place all over Algeria, but these outbreaks had been much exaggerated. The Pan- Islamic movement was largely responsible for the present condition of unrest. All precautionary measures bad been taken, and the authorities were everywhere prepared to take steps to keep the natives in hand.

div.head: TRAVEL IN PALESTINE.
div.p: A correspondent states that a small steam launch has been placed upon the lake oi Galilee, and is now running, in readiness for the autumnal influx of Palestine tourists.

She leaves the wharf on the south shore of the lake on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays, and conveys passengers arriving by train from Carmel to Tiberias, as well as to a point on the north shore, whence there is a bridle road to Safed, the white "city set on a hill," which is perched upon the slope of Mount Hermun.

This enables the traveller to traverse the Valley of Jezreel, catch a glimpse of Nazareth and the Gennesareth sites, and obtain a panoramic glimpse of the greater part of the (Holy Land from Hermon, within the space of three days from coast to coast.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL TRAFFIC.
div.p: According to a return, which was issued last week, the number of vessels which passed through the Suez Canal last year was 4,116, of which 2,481 were British, 600 German, 272 French, 219 Dutch, 70 Russian, 91 Italian, and 139 Austrian. The transit receipts amounted to £4,554,872, a decrease over the previous year of £78,000.

On the 22 of and 23rd October, 19 vessels, of which 9 were northward and 10 southward bound, transited the canal, and p rid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 555,699.37. Of these 9 were British, 6 Germai-, 2 Dutch, 1 Swedish, and 1 Austrian. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 6,313,350.66, and during that Urne 232 vessels transited the Canal, 103 being northward, and 129 southward bound.

div.head: MEAT IMPORTS.
div.p: Mr. Littlewood. the chief veterinary inspector of the Sanitary Department, has suggested to the Ministry of the Interior the following regulations relative to the importation from Ronmania and Servia of livestock to supplement the meat supply in Egypt : —

list.item: That cattle and sheep imported from these two countries be shipped on special steamers at the ports of Conatarzr or Fiurme, and sent direct to Alexandria, where they will be landed at the Old Harbour.
That if the cattle and sheep imported are declared healthy after twenty-four hours' observation, they shall be sent in special trains to the Cairo slaughter house.
That this system, it found satisfactory, be applied in ode of need to the other slaughterhouses of the countries.

div.p: We are glad to hear that the Ministry has approved of Mr. Littlewood's wise suggestion and submitted them to the Quarantine Board.

div.head: WEDDING OF RAMESES.
div.p: In a pamphlet dealing with the work accomplished in' the recent University of Chicago explorations along the Nile, Professor James H. Breasted, who has just arrived in Egypt, States that in the vast temple of Abu Simbel, in Nubia, be found an illustrated account of the wedding of Rameses II. The bride in this case was a Hittite princess. It is plain from the relief and inscriptions that the bride was accompanied by, and was probably given away by, her father. It also is certain that a big wedding feast followed the ceremony.

div.head: FREE THOUGHT. MR. ROBERTSON'S NEW BOOK
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., who took up Egyptian matters with such zeal during the last session and championed Mustapha Pasha Kamel daring his apostolic mission to London, bas just published an interesting work, entitled "A Short History of Free Thought." Mr. Robertson was for some time associated with Mr. Bradlaugb, and edited the latter's organ 'The National Reformer" on the death of that celebrated Atheist in 1891. It is Strange to find snob a fervently orthodox advocate of Islam, as-Kamel, fraternising-with a friend and odontogenic Mr. Bfadlaugh, and the imagination reels at the idea of the faith of the apostle of Pan-Islamism being shaken by European rationalism.

Mr. Robertson's work begins with the very beginning of history, and in his two vohntas covers the whole question up to date, fie shows how ineffectual any kind of free Speculation necessarily is in primitive societies, end how among polytheistic peoples it merely tends to a kind of monotheism. Very effectively he points ont how creed» degenerate without some sort of controversy existing to adapts fifer to the fresh needs of each generation. The account of the free-thinking organisation at present working in each country of modem Europe is extremely interesting. -Theccuchiéioh that forces itself upon the leader of this most careful and learned work is that lovers of speculative truth are quite as rare as genuinely religions persons. For the great mass of humanity life is too full and varied to allow of any Very keen interest outside the warm and cosy world in which they live. Dame Qoiokly'a exhortation to Falataff in his dying moments not to think upon God" is tree to all rime, and Mr. Robertson and his distinguished fore-runners may have found solace in reflating [ that men do not listen more attentively to the theologian than to the freethinker.

div.head: NEW NILE STEAMER.
div.p: Messrs. John I. Thornyoroft and Co.,1 Limited, bave taken an order for a large passenger paddle steamer for Messrs. Thomas Cook and Sons (Egypt), Limited, for tourist service on the Nile. The vessel Will be 230 it. long over all, 51 ft. wide over the paddle-boxes, and will draw 3 ft 4| ins. of water when fully loaded. The speed is to be ten and a-half miles, the machinery consisting of two loco- motive boilers and tri-compound condensing engines. There will be three decks for passengers, and also a sun-deck over all. Steam capstan and windlass and steam steering engine will be fitted, and the vessel will be lighted throughout by electricity. The hull will be of mild steel, the decks and cabin-house of teak. The builders will build the hull at their Woelston Works, Southampton, and afterwards the whole will be unbolted, packed, and shipped to Egypt

div.head: HEAVY STORM AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The first strong meteorological indications that the summer is over and winter fast approaching were given ns yesterday evening. about seven o'clock, when a thunderstorm, | accompanied by vivid and frequent flashes of lightning, broke over Alexandria. The rain came down in torrents and almost swamped - the streets, especially in the suburban districts. Passage on foot Was almost impossible and the cab-drivers reaped a rich harvest The Municipality men tried hard to oops with the deluge ' and make the streets passable, but as most of these are in such a bad state of repair, their task was hopeless.
The condition of the sky to-day gives every indication of showers at frequent intervals.
Heavy rain also began to fall heavily in Cairo about half-past-eight yesterday evening and it was not until after midnight that the weather cleared up.

div.head: MRS. RODOCANACHI'S DEATH.
div.p: At the request which was held on the remains of Mrs. Rodocanachi, whose death in London we recorded yesterday, her daughter, in giving evidence, stated that until recently Mire. Rodocanachi bad enjoyed good health, but about a month ago she became ill, suffering from nervous prostration; she seemed very much improved of late. Though she had said life was no pleasure to her, she had never threatened suicide, and on the day of her death she appeared quite well.

A carpenter, who was in the street at the time of the lady's death, said that he saw the deceased, dad in her night attire, climb through the window and stand on the moulding above a window of the first floor. She then seemed to lose her balance and fell.
Dr. Byrne said that death was due to shock. He was of the opinion that this was a case of sudden impulse without premeditation.
The jury returned a verdict of ' Suicide during temporary insanity."

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will return from Mariout to Montazah this evening. To-morrow morning his Highness will come to Ras-el-Tin palace and attend prayers at the Abou Sinn mosque.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Tabor sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon, and is due here on or about the 8th pros, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO. "ALADDIN"
div.p: "Aladdin" was hardly on a per with 'The Runaway Girl." Of course, the piece was of quite a different character and more of the pantomimio order, but it has distinctly duller. The Widow Twankey is naturally the chief character, and Mr. Harry Cole made all that could have been made 'out of it, by his acting and singing, not to mention his delightful dance. His steps and high kicking Would have done credit to any ballet. 'The finest scene perhaps was the divine ' at the Calcutta Hotel, whére Miss Codas» and Mr. Cole especially distinguished themselves. Miss Corlass was, as usual, delightful as Aladdin, but; as we have said, the part, or rather piece, did not deem to' give her any real scope. Mr. Attwell sang nicely, and had a most striking costume for an attaché. Miss Morra, as the Princess, Mr. Lester, as the Magician, and Mt. Pereival, as the Emperor, were all good, and the Grand Vaier, Mr. Hayden, desèrves mention. The scenery was quite pretty, but, we mùst repeat it, the play, in spite of thé excellent efforts of the performers, Was in itself very disappointing. We shall welcome "The Catch of the Beasor" to-night much more heartily after what we are inclined to call a foil to the other performances.

div.head: THE NOUVEAVTES INCIDENT.
GROSS EXAGGERATION.
div.p: "Al Moayad" makes much of an incident which occured in the Nouveautés Theatre, Cairo a few nights ago. There is the usual story brutal officers, etc., etc., hugely and grossly exaggerated—for political reasons.

An eye-witness informs ns that the Englishmen whose conduct is reprehended by the "Moayad" were certainly a trifle the worse Mr1 drink. Their eonddot,1 however, was merely festive and good humoured. A waiter, Whip rightly objected to one of them Banging his legs ont of a box, very stupidly attempted forte. A scuttle followed. The audience, instead of keeping its head, screeched and shouted, and a general confusion arose, which only terminated in their removal.

The whole affair, according to this version, has been absurdly exaggerated, e.g., where one traveller hung his' legs over the box "Al Mohyad" informs us that no less than six inebriates thrust their feet in the faces of thé spectators—who by the way never seem-to flinch from such conduct on the part of the dads so ses of the theatre. We grant that the culprits behaved in an unbecoming manner, but we have seen many similar incidents among audiences of all nationalities do3e amid general hilarity through the exercise of 4 little tact.

To haul in such an incident by the heels for political purposes seem? rather absurd— unless Sheikh All Youssef honestly believes that brutal violence was used by the individual whom he accuses. Otherwise we shall probably see articles of this sort appearing in the Press

div.head: RIGHT OF FREE SPEECH.
div.p: A carter, who had a difference of opinion with an arbagi on the right of way and expressed his opinions with great heat to a shawish, who intervened, was removed to the Abdin Caracul yesterday. This incident, which left a painful impression on all who witnessed it, is a proof, if proof were needed, of the tyranny of our raters. Where is Lord Cromer's policy of allowing fall freedom to the Prêts, if free speech and free discussion are prohibited 1 Where is our Bill of Rights Had Egypt a Parliament our hearts would not be torn by the constant repetition of such acts of injustice. Argument would be frise and unrestrained in the street as in the council chamber. Eloquence would flourish, and those whom poverty and the meanness of Mr. Douglas Dunlop now compel to drive carts would find the fullest scope for the exercise of their powers of invective in the Senate, etc., etc.

div.head: IMMORALITY ON THE STAGE.
NATIVE PRESS DISAPPROVAL.
div.p: "Al Moayad" writes:—"Both at the Théâtre de Nouveautés and at the Garden Theatre French companies give iron time to time pieces of snob a character that ladies cannot be present at their performance. There are among ns several persons who have gone so far as to critcise Sheikh Salama el Hegazi on account of certain expressions employed in the 'Tasba," although their intention and their setting are the reverse of ignoble. But if our Government cannot entirely prevent foreigners from giving performances that are nauseating and immoral, can it not at least keep them in check I The Capitulations, for example, do not prevent the State from letting the Garden theatre Only to impresarios who Will guarantee that no performances that can be qualified as obscene will be given."

div.head: CRICKET
div.p: S.S. MOLDAVIA v. PORT SAID.

This' mateh, thanks to the energy of Capt. Gordon, Commanding the Moldavia, and a few Englishmen in Port Said, was played at the latter place on the 28rd inst. in delightful weather, and before a most enthusiastic crowd of spectators, chiefly composed of passengers bound for India, China, and Australia.

The matting wicket was beautifully true, but the soit sand surrounding it prevented the ball travelling, a hard out or drive seldom Realising more than two tons, generally only One. Port Said were disposed of for a small total, most of their XI. being very Bbort of practice.

Capt. Greig and Lient. Tamer (brother to those of Essex fame) showed fine all-round cricket, while the fielding of the Moldavia XI. was really first-rate. The keenness of both sides was a treat to watch.
R. H Spooner delighted the crowd by hitting two 6's (clean ont of the ground) and One 4 in an over.

div.head: FAYOUM RACING CLUB.
div.p: It is proposed to form a club with the above title, which sufficiently explains its object. The subscriptions will bé as follows: -L.B. 2 for racing members, and L.E. 1 for non-racing members. Racing members will have the right of entry to the members' stand free, with use of box for one horse and one Servant to club grounds, also free of charge. Non-racing members will have the right of entry to the members' stand free of charge, bat most pay half-fees for use of box or other accommodation if entering horses.

The following gentlemen have kindly consented to act as officers for the first year; President, Mohamed Bey Ati Chararc, Mopdir of Fayoum ; vice president, Hamad Bey Basse); judge, Inspector ofthe Ministry of the Interior (pro tern.) ; deputy judge and treasurer, Mr. H. C. Simpson ; secrets rien, Ahmed Bey Fathi and Mr. R. H. Way ; stewards of the coarse, Messrs. Henry Goat and Elias F. Faraz'i.

A suitable ground for a race-course bee been found near Freetown, and should sufficient subscriptions be forthcoming to justify me formation of the club, work on the coarse and buildings will be pat if hand at once, and it is hoped completed sufficiently for racing to take place by the end of November.

Ainsi qùfe nous le disions hier, la liquidation de fio courant D'est plus à redouter, la plupart dés positions ayant été reportées. La baisse que oèrtaips escomptaient poor eette date n'aura dono pas lien, ou du màîna elle sera insignifiante ; et oela d'autant plus que la Spéculation, résolument optimiste, se met «hx aohats et que la disette monétaire looale tend a s'atténuer. L'élévation du taux d'es- ootnpte, oomme on ne le cesse de le répéter à juste titre, n'est pas en i'ooourence nn indioe de crise, mais plutôt d'un redoublement d'aotivité financière, industrielle et oammer- oiale. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Confiait of Ministers, resumed his duties yesterday at the Ministry of the Interior, where he was visited by el Hamid Pasha Sadik, President of thé Legislative Council, and other high officials.
The Prime Minister paid a visit to Lord Cromer yesterday morning.
Mohamed Shawarby Pasha, member of the Legislative Council, paid a visit to. Lord Cromer yesterday at the British Agency, where he remained about an hour.
Sir R. von Slatin Pasha has left for Khartoum accompanied by his secretary, Ibrahim Effendi Dimitri.
Lewa Bernard Pasha has adjourned his departure from Cairo on account pf work connected with the Sudan Budget. Ho will probably not leave for Khartoum till the second or third week in November.
Lady Wingate left London on Friday on her return to Egypt by the Orient liner Omrah.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place next spring, between Lieutenant- Colonel W- H. Pense, Queen's Bays, Commanding the Egyptten Cavalry, a d Mary, younger daughter of the late T. G, Artindale find of M rs. Artindale, 34, Corowall-gardens.
M. Maekens, Belgian Consol-General, left Alexandria for Cairo yesterday afternoon.
Hopkinson Bey visited the Cairo Police School yesterday and afterwards have an interview with mr. Maoh'ell. The Hakemdar is expected to Return to' Alexandria this afternoon.
Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Summers hopes to go into, their mansion, now being built at Ghizeb before Christinas.
Dr. Morrison is arriving with his family of Port Said on the 1st prox. by this P. & O. S S. Caledonia. He has been spending a «sat part of his holiday motoring all over Scotland.
The celebrated London physician, Sir Stephen Mackenzie, who is paying an early visit to Egypt, is now staying at the Continental Hotel, Cairo.

Vice Admiral Arthur Charles Bèrgqyoe Bromley, who served, in the Abyssinian campaign of 1868, is staying at the Continental Hotel. He was lieutenant of the Chatlenger daring the Survey expedition of 1872-76.
Sir Tatton Sykes has arrived from Sigtond and is staying fit the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said.
The N. G. L. steamer Hohenzellen, which left yesterdayfor Naples and Marseilles, had among her passengers Professors Schmidt and Jung, and Major H. Wynne.
Mr. T. W. Redfern, of the International Steeping Car Company, arrived in Cairo yesterday, and is staying at Shephéard's Hotel.
Mr. Silvestro Rabagliati has been permanently appointed veterinary inspector.
Mustapha Bèy Negoib has been appointed Inspector in the Ministry of the Interior and attached to Keneh Moudirieh.
Mohamed Effendi Abd el Kader, Editor of our contemporary "El Afkar," has been seriously injured by a fall from a tram in the Sharia Daher.
Mr. Wilfrid Scawen Blunt is at present devoting his energies to writing a play in verse, which is to be produced at the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, daring the winter season.

div.head: ADMIRAL FASNSHAWB DEAD.
div.p: Admiral Sir Edward Fanshawe is dead. (R.)

Sir Edward Genyss Fanshawe, G.C.B., son of the late General B. Fanshawe, C.B., R.E., and grandson, by his mother, of General Sir Tt. Dalrymple. was born on November 14, 1814, and entered the Navy at the age of 14. He was made Admiral in 1876 and retired in.1,880. Prom 1865 66 he was Lord of the Admirality, and four years later was appointed .Commander-in Chief of the North American and West Indian station. He was president of the Royal Naval Collage, Greenwich, for two years, and his last year of service was pasted fit Commander-In-Chief at Portsmouth.

non sans raison d'ailleurs, car wui oomuio , - présager une saison d'affaires exceptionnelle ra Moudirieh par soite de la prospérité croissante du pays.

La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development a réactionné à 92 1/4. Les Improvj ( ments ont progressé à 6-6 1/16. L'action Entre prises Immobilières et Travaux a é étraitée à , 4 7/16 1/2 ; la part de fondateur a tait 99 100.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont bénéficié ! de 3 francs à 271 et la Frigorifiqae de 1/16 à i 4 7/8. Ei bonne tenue, l'Anglo-Amerioen Nile a gagné 1/4 de livre à 5 7/8. Las Automobil s ont été àceoiées à 6 1/8-3/16 et la part de fondateur à 12 Les Cairo-Suburban ont é'é cotés à 4 3/4.

Les Markets ont faibli à 25 sh. 6 Les New Egyptian sont remontés à 33 sh. 9-34, les Hooker à 11/8-3/16 et les Abdy à 1 5/16

Noas avons annoncé qae, par suite de l'im palsion donnée aux travaux du chemin de fer qai reliera la Haute Egypte aux Oisia occidentales, on espère qae la ligue pourra être ouverte au trafic dans les premiers mois de l'année prochaine.

Or, on pent voir actuellement, aux boréaux de la Corporation of Western E ,rypf, au Caire ' et à Londres, des échantillons des essais di ' vers de oulture faits sur les terrains de la Compagnie, terrains dont la superficie totale s'élève à 600,000 foddaus et dont une partie, à Khargeh, est déjà.irrigaée au moyen de puits artésiens. Ces échantillons consisteut eu oé réales, dattes et notamment eu coton. Lealt; espèces de coton récolté» consistent en Afifi. Abassi, Yanovîoh et Achmouni. Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchandises
The Admiralty has decided to constitute a distinct set called the Home Fleet, the head- quarters of which will be at Sheerne.

The distribution of ships between the Channel, Mediterranean, and Atlantic Reserve Fleets will be altered in order to permit the strengthening of the nnclens crews and the organisation of the Home Fleet.
No ships will be paid rtf, do men will.be sent to barracks, and no alteration will be made in the proportion of officers and men serving afloat.
The changes will be gradual in 'Order to obviate dislocation. (Neuter)

The news of the constitution of the Home Fleet is generally applauded. It is regarded as disposing of the recent rumors of the delegation of important to the reserves for the purpose of economy. „ (Reuter)

div.head: GOVERNMENT AND EDUCATION BILL STRONG INTIMATION TO THE LORDS

div.p: It is understood that the Government has- intimated to the Lords that the postponement of the discussion on the Education Bill will only result in the prolongation of the session. The Govern ment is prepared to keep Parliament sitting till after Christmas in order to carry the Bill through.
The Opposition may move the postponement', hot it is unlikely that this motion would be generally supported. (Reuter)
The House of Commons is occupied on the
committee stage of the Plural Voting Bill, __________________ ___
which is expected to continue for the rest of tomorrow the week. (Tenter)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

Egypt has again been the predominating factor in the money market this week. In our last report we gave it as a general opinion that two millions more gold would be required before the Egyptian demands would be satisfied, at the same time pointing ont there were soma older members of the market who thought this overstated. These latter gentlemen, however, do not appear to have been well posted or op to-date in their conclusions, for £1.010,000 in gold was shipped to Egypt at the beginning of the current week, and we understand that another £1,000,000 will leave the Bank to-night. It looks as if a farther £500,000 will be required before present demande will be satisfied. A helping factor in the situation are the dividends on the Unified, which at present are being made ose of fi r remittances, these being equivalent to gold in Egypt, and much less expensive to transmit.

The uncertainty as regards Egypt, and also the possibility of further gold requirements for the Argentine Republic and the United States all tend to have a serions effect upon the money market. Three months' Bank bills were yesterday penitently taken at 4| %, but 4 | was nearer the current price last night.

It is well-known that the Bank directors are désirons of avoiding a 6 per cent. Bank rate, but if the present heavy demands for gold continue it looks to ns as if this will be inevitable before the end rf the year.

Having written so much, we learn that a notice has just been posted in the Bank of England raising the rate to S per cent. Needless to say this was quite unexpected, and has owned consternation all-round. Many people ask why at the Bank directors' meeting yesterday some bent was not given that a 6 per cent. rate was in sight No doubt the directors have a very good answer; at the same time these Bnddon notions do give rise to a great deal of comment not very complimentary to the Book directors. Certainly thé man in the street would appear to bo quite justified in argoing that Bunch a drastic step on the day immediately following Thursday, when tensional meeting is held and the Bank statement is given but, calls for comment.

No doubt the enormous withdrawal of £1,000,000 for Egypt to-day had considerable influence upon the decision of the Bank direotora, but it ia more than probable that there are o-ber effluences at work as well, and the feeling that this may be ao naturally has the most disturbing effect in the City. Tie backward movement which had taken place in the Now York Exchange during the last few weeks had already teen oansipg some anxiety, and although loan money at that contre nommai ds only about 5%. there is always the uncertainty as to what tomorrow might bring forth. The rate, however, this afternoon is a little bit firmer, but still the outlook is far from re assuring

Of course, it will scarcely sait our neighbors to have the Bank rate standing at 6%. and there is always the possibility that the Paris market may come to the rescue at any moment, the rate of exchange this afternoon, 25.214, showing that tendency. On the other hand, the German Bank rate, which also stands at 6%, will in all probability be advanced another point

For the present the distorting foaling ri fleets, itself in wide quotations in rates. The seven-day loans, which this morning were down at 4%, are expected to fetch 4} to 5% tomorrow, and the discount market is talking of 5} to 5f% as the current rate. In the meantime, however, the Joint Stock Banks have only advanced the deposit rate to 4%

The Bank return this week thaws that the total reserve has been augmented by £572,000. The mar urity of bills at the Bank is reflected in a prediction of two millions in the "Other Securities." Public Deposits have increased by nearly 1} million», while there is a shrinkage of almost three million in "Other Deposits." The popcorn of reserve to liabilities has risen 2.3 per cent, to 3T.7.%.
The Stock Markets,

The monetary situation has bad a very depressing i fleet upon stocks and shares. The actual withdrawals of gold have not been the only source of anxiety, but the uncertainty regarding the future, and the anticipations of a still higher Bank rate before a normal condition is reached in the money market. All the week Egypt has loomed in the markets as Gotor to be afraid of, and the consequence has been a doll and lifeless in most sections, gilt-edged stocks having suffered considerably.

This position has been very much accentuated by to-day's ri-e in the Bank rate, as above explained, with the result that gilt-edged stocks have fallen away to a considerable extent, while in other sections quotations are lower
At (be same time the near approach of the winner season, and the dose of the Egyptian holidays, are being followed by a revival in
On the announcement of a six per cent. Bank rate this morning they fell to 85 } for cash, and close to-night at 85}f.
Foreign Bonds.

Russians have been a strong feature in the international market, and the Fives have been quoted 7} discount, and the Fours 74. They have since fallen away, however, and the scrip of the new loan leaves oft to night at 8} discount and the Fours at 73. It is satisfactory to notice a continued increase of confidence in these bonds, for, despitè the general of markets, the present price of the new Fives is a striking contrast to the Agonist quotations, which were in the neighborhood of 12 discount. Barring a further reaction in Russia, it looks cm if the script might he somewhere near par before the end of the year.

Japanese stokes at one time were inclined to harder, bat have lost the lead. Yesterday the 4 per cent. cf 1915 lost, the Second 4}% dropped j), and several of the other stocks }. They show farther losses to-day.

It is now practically certain that the conversion of the six per cent. loans will not take place until the New Year, aa the present is considered an inopportune time to make the change—though, judging by 'he great snoozes which attended past issues, it may be safely stared that the Japanese Government would even now have no difficulty in getting the necessary capital. Whether they would obtain as good terms as at some future date another matter. Evidently their Commissionner has advised that they can do better by waiting, and in view of the big Bank rate we quite foodoir in the advisability of waiting.
Homo Ralls.

This market has been under the influent of the gilt edged section, and there is still some uneasiness with respect to labour troubles. The recent meetings of draymen, and the events on the Clyde had an unsettling effect from which the market has not yet recovered. Throughout the week the tone has been doll, and with two or three exceptions the movements have been downwards. Great Northern Deferred displayed some firmness yesterday, this quotation, after being 40}, loosing at 41}. Dover "A" were also well supported, and rose (rom 46} to 47}.

The traffic returns for last week were fairly satisfactory. I he North Eastern again topped the list with a gain of £12,900, and the Great Northern and Great Western had increases of £4,000 and £3,600. The London and South Western, on the other hand, reported a loss of £1,700. In the other cases the returns were featureless.
Americans.

To-day's announcement of a further increase in the Bank rate immediately sent American shares down from a dollar to two dollars. The tone has continued heavy throughout the afternoon, and some heavy losses 'have been marked. Milwaukee have dropped 3 at 179 Baltimore and Ohio 2} at 124} New York Central 2 at 141} Union Pacifies lj at 190}, Southern Pacifies 1} at 95}. and Canadian Pacifies 2} at 183}.
Hudson Bays were largely dealt in in the early part of the week and up to Wednesday night gained 6 points at 104. When the boom let ceased they eased off to 102}, at which they dose to night.
Egyptians.

There has been quite a good market in Egyptians, and a fair business has been done. National Banks of Egypt have been active, and rose to 27-ft buyers, but to-night are easier at 27}, thing quite firm at this price. Agriool tarai Banks are steady at 9}}, with not maybe doing. Daira Sanieh Ordinary are unchanged at 16}, but the Deferred have been offered, and are a poor market at 96. Delta Preference Bearer are better and close 19}, while Delta Land and Investments are also good at 3}. There has been a large business done in Land and General Trust, and the price has advanced steadily from par to about 3/-s, premium, oligo buyers at 2/9 premium. Khédivial Mail Ordinary are also wanted at 85/-s. Egyptian Estates are 2, and Union Forçieie 6}-}. Land Bank of Egypt are quiet at 9}

Egyptian Markets are also up to 28/s., and Salt at d Soda after being 24/6 bid, close at 24/ s. rather sellers. Corporation of Western Egypt are unhanged at fo premirm, and Daira Sugar at 2}-}. Bank of Ronmaria 6re 10. New Egyptian have also boon very largely dealt in, and are up to 1}}.
M Inlng.

The South African market bas generally been dull, although there have been one or two bright periods. Rumors to the effect that the East Rand amalgamation scheme had been abandoned caused Kaffirs to be especially weak on Wednesday, dhd East Rands showed somewhat considerable relapse. Yesterday morning they received some support, but weakened again in the afternoon,, lower at 4. They are now 3}}. Rand Mines close at 5.

The boom in Yaal River shares seems to have subsided, and the closing quotation 3 shows little change on our last. Yesterday De Beers Deferred were a good market, and left off A higher at 20. They close today at 19}.
The Egyptian section centime to mark time. Only a small amount of business has

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
